The presence of sulfur-containing impurities in natural gas not only diminishes its utilization value, but also results in the emission of sulfur-containing pollutants. In this study, a Cu-Ce bimetallic-loaded MCM-41 catalyst was prepared by ammonia evaporation method for the catalytic hydrolysis of carbonyl sulfide (COS). The desulfurization efficiency of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 can reach a 100 % COS removal rate and maintain for 3.5 h. CuO furnishes the predominant weakly acidic and weakly basic sites for the desulfurization process, which are conducive to the adsorption of COS. Meanwhile, CeOx provides a greater abundance of moderately basic sites for the desulfurization process, which help to improve the removal efficiency of COS. The incorporation of Ce into the catalyst enhances the resistance to sulfur poisoning of Cu and prolongs the lifespan of the catalyst. The incorporation of Ce is capable of transforming the strongly basic sites on the surface of Cu25/MCM-41 into moderately basic sites, avoiding excessive oxidation of H2S. Additionally, the introduction of Ce offers a degree of protection for CuO, which improves the ability of the catalyst to resist sulfur poisoning. The combined effect of Cu and Ce was found to be instrumental in enhancing the adsorption of COS and in slowing down the oxidation of H2S. The reduction of Cu2+ and Ce3+ indicated their direct participation in the oxidation of H2S. Firstly, COS adsorbed on the catalyst surface is converted into H2S and CO2 through a catalytic hydrolysis reaction. Subsequently, H2S adsorbed on the catalyst surface undergoes partial oxidation to sulfide, and partial further oxidation by oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface to S, SO3 2-, and SO4 2-, which results in the toxic deactivation of the catalyst. Graphical abstract Cu and Ce provide weak and moderately alkaline sites for COS hydrolysis . The hydrolysis product H2S is further oxidized into S, SO3 2-, and SO4 2- species under the action of oxygen-containing groups. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Synergistic effects Bimetallic Carbonyl sulfide Catalytic hydrolysis MCM-41 Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction In comparison to traditional fossil fuels, natural gas possesses a number of advantageous characteristics, including a high calorific value, abundant reserves, low cost, and promising applications in industrial production and in daily life [1,2]. The composition of natural gas includes a range of sulfur-containing species, such as hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and organic sulfur compounds (e.g., COS), which can influence the purity and utility of natural gas. The combustion of raw natural gas without deep desulfurization generates sulfur dioxide (SO₂) and other sulfur-containing compounds [3]. These sulfur-containing compounds not only pollute the atmosphere, but also jeopardize human health, corrode equipment and piping, and pose a significant safety hazard to production and life. The combination of sulfur-containing compounds and sulfur-containing compounds is a major factor in the development of the natural gas industry [4,5]. The technologies employed for the removal of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) from natural gas are currently well-established. The most prevalent techniques for this purpose include wet desulfurization and dry desulfurization [6]. However, the efficacy of these methods for organic sulfur is relatively limited [7]. Organic sulfur impurities in natural gas are primarily COS. Various methods for removing COS have been developed, including adsorptive desulfurization, catalytic oxidation, catalytic hydrogenation, and catalytic hydrolysis [8–11]. Of these, catalytic hydrolysis has the advantage of low energy consumption, mild reaction conditions, and high desulfurization efficiency. As a result, it has been the subject of extensive investigation on the removal of COS [12]. At present, the catalysts used for catalytic hydrolysis of COS mainly include aluminum-based catalysts, iron-based catalysts, titanium-based catalysts, rare earth metal-based catalysts, and carbon-based catalysts [13–17]. These metal-based catalysts have poor sulfur resistance and are easily poisoned by sulfur during the catalytic hydrolysis of COS, thus affecting their catalytic performance. Carbon-based catalysts have rich pore structures, but it is easy to adsorb the reactant H2O during the removal of COS [18,19]. Excessive water will block the pores of the activated carbon and hinder the reaction. Molecular sieves have good water and sulfur resistance, which can solve the defects of the above two catalyst carriers [20,21]. Molecular sieves have more regular and orderly pore structures, larger specific surface areas, and adjustable surface functional groups, which are beneficial to the mass transfer, adsorption, and reaction of reactants, making them suitable for catalytic reactions. Many previous studies have shown that molecular sieves have good adsorption properties for organic sulfur [22–27]. However, few studies have investigated the use of molecular sieves as catalyst supports for the catalytic hydrolysis of COS. Therefore, molecular sieves have a very broad application prospect in the catalytic hydrolysis of COS. Compared with other molecular sieves, MCM-41 still retains a large amount of -OH after calcination [28,29]. The presence of a large amount of -OH is conducive to the adsorption and removal of acidic gases. Furthermore, the larger specific surface area of MCM-41 is beneficial for the distribution and fixation of active metals, and its highly regular and ordered mesoporous structure promotes the diffusion and mass transfer of reactants [30]. Therefore, MCM-41 has potential application value for catalytic hydrolysis of COS. Since pure MCM-41 lacks active sites for the catalytic hydrolysis of COS, active components need to be added to it before it can be used for catalytic desulfurization [29]. In the field of catalytic hydrolysis of COS, the active components of the catalysts are typically transition metal oxides, alkali metal oxides, rare earth metal oxides, and surface functional groups. Song et al. modified walnut shell biochar (WSB) catalysts with Fe and Cu metal oxides, and alkaline functional groups were employed for the simultaneous catalytic hydrolysis of COS and carbon disulfide (CS2) [31]. The results demonstrated that Fe2O3, CuO, and -OH (KOH) were the primary active components for the catalytic hydrolysis of COS and CS2. Li et al. synthesized Ce-doped hydrotalcite-like compound (HTLC)-derived oxides for the catalytic hydrolysis of COS [32]. The results demonstrated that doping 3 wt.% of Ce (3Ce-ZnNiAl) led to a 138 % increase in the catalytic hydrolysis activity of COS compared to unmodified ZnNiAl. The doping of Ce in ZnNiAl results in the incorporation of Ce into the NiO network, which resulted in the generation of numerous chemisorbed oxygen and basic sites for the adsorption and dissociation of COS. Xu et al. prepared a Ce-Ox@ZrO2 catalyst by doping Ce into ZrO2 to create a composite material [33]. The experimental results demonstrated that the addition of Ce effectively increased the specific surface area of the catalyst, which enhanced the adsorption, diffusion, and reaction of the reactant. It was observed that the surface metal modification can greatly improve the catalytic hydrolysis performance of the catalyst. Therefore, combining the surface hydroxyl groups of MCM-41 with the catalytic properties of metal oxides, it can be used for the catalytic hydrolysis of COS. In this study, Cu-Ce bimetallic modified hydrolysis catalysts were prepared and evaluated for their potential for synergistic desulfurization with different metals. Furthermore, the desulfurization constitutive relationships, deactivation products and deactivation mechanisms of the catalysts were investigated through a series of characterization techniques, including XRD, SEM, BET, XPS, CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, and FTIR. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of MCM-41 The reagents utilized in this experiment, including cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, AR), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, AR), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, AR), hydrochloric acid (HCl, ACS), ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH, GR), and cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, AR), were procured from Macklin Ltd. Additionally, copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, AR) was procured from Aladdin. All reagents can be utilized without the necessity of additional purification. The MCM-41 carrier was synthesized via a hydrothermal synthesis process and prepared as follows: Initially, 7.2892 g of CTAB were dissolved in 150 ml of deionized water. This solution was then stirred magnetically in a water bath at 30 °C for 30 min. Subsequently, 1.6 g of NaOH was dissolved in 50 ml of deionized water. This solution was then added to the aforementioned CTAB solution, and the resulting mixture was continued to be stirred for an additional 30 min at 30 °C. Once the solution had been clarified, 34.722 g of TEOS was added dropwise to the mixed solution, which was being vigorously stirred at the time. The pH was then adjusted to 11 with 2 mol/L HCl, and the resulting milky white suspension was stirred for a further 3 h. The milky white suspension was transferred to a 100 ml PTFE-lined high-pressure reactor and subjected to hydrothermal reaction at 110 °C for 48 h. Following the completion of the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and the solids were filtered and washed with deionized water until reaching a neutral pH. The filtered solids were then dried at 100 °C for 12 h, resulting in the formation of a white powder. The powder was subjected to a roasting process in a muffle furnace at 540 °C for a duration of 6 h, with a heating rate of 2 °C per minute, in order to obtain the MCM-41 carrier. 2.1.2 Preparation of CuX-CeY/MCM-41 CuX-CeY/MCM-41 catalysts were synthesized via the ammonia evaporation method, and the catalyst synthesis schematic diagram was shown in Fig. S1. Initially, 1 g of MCM-41 carrier was added to 80 ml of deionized water and magnetically stirred in a water bath at 50 °C for 15 min. Once complete dispersion was achieved, copper nitrate trihydrate was added as the copper source and stirred for an additional hour. Subsequently, the solution was adjusted to pH 9 with 2 mol/L ammonia and stirred for a period of 2 h at 50 °C in order to facilitate the evaporation of ammonia. The solution was vacuum filtered and rinsed with deionized water 3 times, then dried in a drying oven at 100 °C for 12 h to obtain the powder. The powder was then calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 3 h, with a heating rate of 5 °C/min, to obtain CuX/MCM-41. The synthesis of CeY/MCM-41 was achieved by replacing copper nitrate trihydrate with cerium nitrate trihydrate in the aforementioned steps, with the remaining steps remaining identical. The synthesis of CuX-CeY/MCM-41 was achieved through an ammonia evaporation method, following the same procedure as that used for CuX/MCM-41. In this method, the mass percentage of CuO and CeO2 in the carrier MCM-41, represented by X and Y, respectively, was maintained constant. In this study, the ratio of Cu and Ce is based on the mass ratio of the metal oxides. To verify the mass ratio of the metals in the catalysts, ICP-OES characterization was performed, and the results are displayed in Table S1. The preparation of the catalyst involved the loading of 25 % by weight of CuO on 1 g of MCM-41, followed by the subsequent loading of 5 % by weight of CeO2 on top of the Cu25/MCM-41 catalyst, resulting in the Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalyst. Consequently, the theoretical ratio of Cu to Ce in the Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalyst was determined to be 3.94:1. In fact, the ICP-OES characterization results showed that the Cu:Ce was 3.97:1, which was close to the theoretical value. This indicates that the synthesis method was reliable and reproducible. Subsequent to the incorporation of Ce, the quantity of Cu in the Cu25/MCM-41 catalyst underwent a modest reduction, attributable to the partial coverage of Cu by Ce. The variation in Ce and Cu content was found to be minimal, suggesting that the Cu content remained relatively stable. 2.1.3 Evaluation of desulfurization activity The tests for COS removal were conducted in a fixed-bed quartz reactor at 70 °C, with a quartz tube of 6 mm inner diameter The COS (0.2 % COS in N2) in the gas cylinder was diluted to 100 ppm with N2 (99.99 %) and mixed with 1.4 % vol of water vapor at a total gas flow rate of 50 ml/min. The present study examined the catalytic hydrolytic conversion of COS in the presence of CH4 as the background gas. The experimental results showed that the removal of COS was able to reach 100 % with a stable lifetime under CH4 atmosphere, which indicated that there was almost no interaction between the catalyst and CH4. The inlet mixture contained 1.4 % H2O, while the outlet mixture exhibited a slightly lower percentage of 1.38 %. The reduced H2O was predominantly engaged in the hydrolysis reaction of COS, thereby indicating that the catalyst exerted minimal influence on the water content of the natural gas. Thereafter, the diluted COS was introduced to a quartz tube containing 300 mg of catalyst at a total gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 10,000 h-1. A FULI 9790plus gas chromatograph was employed for the analysis of the concentration of COS at the inlet and outlet of the reactor, as well as the concentration of H2S and CO2 (hydrolysis products). The rate of removal of COS was determined by calculating the concentration of COS at the inlet and outlet, as illustrated by the following Eq. (1): (1) COS removal rate ( % ) = [ COS ] in − [ COS ] out [ COS ] in × 100 % In Eq. (1), the concentrations of COS in the inlet and outlet streams, are designated as [COS]in and [COS]out respectively. 2.2 Characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) images were obtained using a TESCAN CLARA cold field emission scanning electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 5 keV and 15 keV, respectively. A powder small-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted on a Rigaku SmartLab SE diffractometer using a copper target (0.154 nm) at a scanning speed of 0.5°/min, spanning a range of 1° to 8°. A powder X-ray diffraction analysis was conducted on a Panaco X-Pert PRO diffractometer using a copper target (0.154 nm) from 10° to 80° at a scanning speed of 5°/min. A 100 mg sample was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h on a JW-BK100 specific surface area and pore size analyzer. Thereafter, the nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were determined, and the specific surface area and pore size distributions of the samples were analyzed by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) tests were performed using a Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi. In particular, the vacuum of the analysis chamber was 1 × 10–9 mBar, the excitation source was Al Kα-rays (hv=1486.68 eV), the operating voltage was 15 kV, the filament current was 10 mA, and the signal accumulation was performed for 5–10 cycles. The test pass energy (Passing-Energy) was 30 eV with a step size of 0.05 eV and was calibrated using C1s=284.80 eV. The binding energy was calibrated as an energy standard. The H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) test was conducted on a TP-5080-D fully automated multifunctional adsorbent apparatus (Xianquan Ltd.). 100 mg of the sample was initially treated in a He gas stream (30 ml/min) at 300 °C for 1 h, then cooled to 50 °C. Thereafter, the sample was passed through a 7 % H2/He gas mixture (30 ml/min) at an elevated temperature rate of 10 °C/min to 750 °C for reduction. The surface acidity and alkalinity of the catalysts were analyzed using NH3/CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD). 100 mg of the samples were initially processed in a He gas stream (30 ml/min) at 300 °C for 1 h. They were then cooled to 50 °C and passed through a mixture of 7 % NH3/He or CO2/He (30 ml/min) for 30 min until saturation was reached. Thereafter, a He gas stream (30 ml/min) was used to purge for 60 min to remove weakly physically adsorbed NH3/CO2 on the surface. The apparatus was purged for 60 min to remove any weakly physisorbed NH3/CO2 on the surface. Finally, the samples were desorbed under a He atmosphere at an elevated temperature rate of 10 °C/min up to 750 °C. During the desorption process, the NH3/CO2-TPD curves were recorded from 50 °C to 750 °C by means of a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectrometer were obtained using IR Tracer-100 by scanning 32 times with the scanning spectral range from 400 cm-1 to 4000 cm-1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 COS catalytic hydrolysis experiments The desulfurization performance of pure MCM-41, transition metal Cu-loaded MCM-41 (Cu25/MCM-41), rare earth metal Ce-loaded MCM-41 (Ce25/MCM-41), and Cu and Ce co-loaded MCM-41 (Cu25Ce5/MCM-41) was evaluated. The COS removal efficiency and product concentration changes are illustrated in Fig. 1 and Fig. 2 . The experimental results indicated that unmodified MCM-41 exhibited minimal COS removal, with a rate of <5 %. Additionally, the concentrations of H2S and CO2 in the product were nearly undetectable. These findings suggest that the removal of COS by MCM-41 is primarily achieved through an adsorption process. However, the adsorption capacity of MCM-41 for COS was observed to be relatively low. The desulfurization performance of Cu25/MCM-41 modified with Cu was markedly enhanced, with the COS removal rate reaching over 90 %. Concomitantly, there was a discernible generation of CO2 in the product, which indicated that the introduction of Cu altered the COS removal process from adsorption to catalytic hydrolysis. Furthermore, the low concentration of H2S generated from COS hydrolysis suggests that the hydrolysis product H2S was adsorbed on the catalyst surface or underwent additional chemical reactions. However, the desulfurization effect was not enhanced by Ce25/MCM-41 modified with Ce. In comparison to Cu25/MCM-41, Ce25/MCM-41 exhibited a lower CO2 concentration and a higher H2S concentration. This suggests that the hydrolysis performance of Ce is inferior. This was attributed to the inferior desulfurization performance of catalysts comprising a single metal, cerium, as the active component [34]. Furthermore, the addition of Ce leads to changes in the pore structure. Following the simultaneous loading of Cu and Ce onto MCM-41, the COS removal rate of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 has been observed to reach in excess of 90 %. Furthermore, the desulfurization lifetime has been demonstrated to be increased by 80 %. This suggests that Ce and Cu have a synergistic effect on desulfurization. As shown in Table 1 , the desulfurization performance of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 is improved compared with the previous catalysts. Furthermore, Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 demonstrated the capacity to sustain CO₂ production over an extended period, suggesting that the incorporation of Ce may enhance the catalytic hydrolysis performance of Cu. As illustrated in Fig. 2b, the CO2 content produced by the catalytic hydrolysis of COS by Cu25/MCM-41 and Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 gradually decreased with the decrease of desulfurization performance. This phenomenon shows that the CO2 produced by COS hydrolysis is completely carried out by the airflow. The adsorption of H₂S on the catalyst surface affects not only the adsorption and catalytic removal of COS but also, over time, leads to a gradual degradation of the catalyst performance. This is true for both Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 and Cu25/MCM-41. As demonstrated in Figs. 1 and 2, for Cu25Ce5/MCM-41, within the initial 3.5 h, the conversion of COS and the production of CO2 remained relatively constant. Subsequent to this time period, the CO2 content exhibited a slight increase over the amount of COS converted, which can be attributed to the desorption of CO2 that had been partially adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Overall, the conversion of COS remains in accordance with the material balance. The catalyst regeneration performance tests were supplemented. Initially, the deactivated catalysts were immersed in a 2 mol/L NH4OH solution for a duration of 3 h. Thereafter, they underwent a drying process at a temperature of 100 °C for a period of 12 h. The regenerated catalysts were subsequently obtained through a roasting procedure in an air atmosphere at a temperature of 400 °C for a duration of 2 h. Thereafter, the regenerated catalysts were subjected to a drying process at 100 °C for an additional 12 h. Then, they underwent a roasting step at 400 °C for 2 h. The desulfurization performance of the regenerated catalyst is depicted in Fig. S2. The regenerated catalyst demonstrated the capacity to ensure 100 % COS removal, thereby affirming its recyclability. To further elucidate the catalytic effect of the catalysts, a comprehensive characterization was conducted to examine the physical and chemical properties of the catalysts in depth. 3.2 Morphological and structural characteristics analysis The morphology and structure of the catalyst exert a significant influence on its desulfurization efficacy. The SEM images and EDS results for the various catalysts are presented in Fig. 3 . The MCM-41 (Fig. 3a) synthesized in this study exhibits a high degree of particle agglomeration, resulting in a rough surface morphology. The smooth surface morphology of Cu25/MCM-41 (Fig. 3b) obtained after loading Cu indicates that the Cu component can effectively cover and fill the voids on the surface of MCM-41. The surface granularity of the catalyst Ce25/MCM-41 (Fig. 3c) obtained after loading Ce became smaller and many pores were formed, which facilitated the enhancement of the adsorption and diffusion of reactant molecules on the surface [33]. The surface morphology of the Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalyst (Fig. 3d) exhibited a more pronounced roughness in comparison with that of the Cu25/MCM-41 catalyst. This was accompanied by the formation of new pores, which enhanced the adsorption and diffusion of COS and H2O, thereby favoring the removal of organic sulfur. The BET method was employed to examine the alterations in the pore structure of the catalysts prior to and following metal loading. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of MCM-41, Cu25/MCM-41, Ce25/MCM-41, and Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 are illustrated in Fig. 4 , and the corresponding specific pore structure data are presented in Table 2 . The BET specific surface area of MCM-41 was 927 m2/g. In contrast, the BET specific surface areas of Cu25/MCM-41 and Ce25/MCM-41 decreased to 347 m2/g and 314 m2/g, respectively. This reduction was attributed to the clogging of the MCM-41 pores by the oxides of Cu and Ce, which also led to a reduction in pore volume. The average pore sizes of Cu25/MCM-41 (3.91 nm) and Ce25/MCM-41 (3.87 nm) were comparatively higher than those of MCM-41 (2.87 nm). This increase in pore size is a consequence of the incorporation of Cu- and Ce-species into the MCM-41 framework. This clogging of the small pores is in addition to the generation of mesopores by the Cu- and Ce-species. The average pore size of the catalyst Cu25/MCM-41 (3.87 nm), prepared by the addition of a small amount of Ce, Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 (3.78 nm), exhibited a decrease, while the pore volume and the specific surface area demonstrated a slight increase in comparison to that of Cu25/MCM-41. The pore volume distribution of the related catalysts was listed separately, and the results are shown in Table S2. From the pore volume distribution of the samples (Table S2), it can be seen that the pore volume of Ce25/MCM-41 in the 10–50 nm pore size range is significantly larger than that of MCM-41, and the pore volume of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 in this pore size range is also significantly larger than that of Cu25/MCM-41, which proves that the addition of Ce forms new pores, and the pore diameters of these new pores are mainly distributed in the range of 10–50 nm. Fig. 4 depicts the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of MCM-41, Cu25/MCM-41, Ce25/MCM-41, and Cu25Ce5/MCM-41. All exhibit type IV isotherms, indicative of the typical adsorption-desorption isotherms observed in mesoporous materials. This is further corroborated by the pore size distributions illustrated in Fig. 4b. The MCM-41 displays a type H1 hysteresis loop, whereas the remaining four catalysts exhibit a characteristic H4-type hysteresis loop. The presence of this H4-type hysteresis loop can be attributed to the attachment of Cu and Ce within the pores, which results in a structural change [35]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) is employed to ascertain the physical phases present in the catalyst and to identify the principal components of Cu and Ce on the catalyst surface. The XRD characteristic peaks of mesoporous molecular sieves typically manifest at 2θ values between 0.5°−10° [36]. As illustrated in Fig. 5 , the (100) peak of MCM-41 (JCPDS 49–1712) emerges at 2θ of 2.2°, while the (110) and (200) peaks manifest at approximately 4° [37]. Following the loading of Cu, a decrease in the intensity of the (100), (110), and (200) peaks of MCM-41 was observed, accompanied by a shift to the right. This indicates that the metallic Cu component was effectively loaded on all crystal planes of MCM-41. Following the loading of Ce, the height of the (100) peak of MCM-41 was observed to decrease and shift to the right. Additionally, the (110) and (200) peaks were no longer present, indicating that the Ce component exhibited a higher degree of coverage on the surface of MCM-41. In contrast, the position of the (100) peak of Cu25/MCM-41 remained unaltered upon the introduction of a limited quantity of the Ce component. However, the intensity was noted to diminish, and the (110) and (120) peaks were no longer discernible. This suggests that Ce forms a coverage on all three crystal surfaces of Cu25/MCM-41. As illustrated in Fig. 5, following the loading of Cu, the characteristic peaks of MCM-41 are observed at 2θ = 22° for the Cu25/MCM-41 catalyst, while the characteristic peaks of CuO (JCPDS 48–1548) manifest at 36°. Following the loading of Ce, the characteristic peak of CeO2 (JCPDS 34–0394) was observed at 28.5° for the Ce25/MCM-41 catalyst. The characteristic peaks of MCM-41, CuO, and CeO2 were evident for the Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalyst. The weaker intensity of the characteristic peaks of CuO and CeO2 was attributed to the smaller size of the loaded metal particles [38,39]. The XRD results demonstrated that the Cu and Ce on the catalyst surface were predominantly in the CuO and CeO2 forms, respectively, which contributed to the enhancement of the catalytic hydrolysis COS performance. In conjunction with the findings of the desulfurization trials, it can be concluded that CuO represents the primary active component in catalytic hydrolysis. During the process of COS catalyzed by Cu25Ce5/MCM-41, a small amount of CeO2 formed new pores on the surface of Cu25/MCM-41. These pores facilitated the adsorption and diffusion of COS and H2O [33], enabling the reactants to come into full contact and reaction with CuO, thereby enhancing the desulfurization performance of the catalyst. 3.3 Surface chemical characterization analysis The surface acid-base sites and types of active species of the catalyst were examined using CO2-TPD/NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, and XPS, with a view to analyzing their effects on the adsorption and catalytic hydrolysis of COS. The results of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of copper and cerium for various catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 . As illustrated in Fig. 6a, the Cu species present in Cu25/MCM-41 and Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 predominantly exist in the form of Cu2+. As illustrated in Fig. 6b, Ce in Ce25/MCM-41 and Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 predominantly exists in the forms of Ce4+ and Ce3+. The addition of a small amount of Ce had no significant effect on the Cu species in Cu25Ce5/MCM-41, nor on the ratio of Ce4+ and Ce3+. This demonstrates that the simultaneous loading of Cu and Ce does not affect each other's component species. Acidic sites mainly affect the physisorption and chemisorption processes of COS on the catalyst surface. The NH3-TPD method was employed to identify the acidic species present on the sample surface and to quantify the number of corresponding sites. As illustrated in Fig. 7 , the acidic strength of the catalysts can be classified into three categories: weak acid (50–300 °C), medium-strong acid (300–600 °C), and strong acid (600–800 °C) based on the position of the desorption peaks of NH3. The number of weakly acidic sites was markedly elevated by MCM-41 following the loading of Cu and Ce fractions, respectively. Furthermore, the strengths of the weakly acidic sites of the catalysts were observed to be more pronounced in the case of Cu loading than those of Ce25/MCM-MCM-41, which suggests that CuO is capable of providing a greater number of weak acid sites. Both Cu25/MCM-41 and Ce25/MCM-41 yielded considerable quantities of medium-strong acid sites in comparison to MCM-41. However, the strength of the medium-strong acid sites differed significantly between the two catalysts. The surface of Ce25/MCM-41 exhibited a higher strength of medium-strong acid than that of Cu25/MCM-41. In conjunction with the findings of the desulfurization experiment, this indicates that the relatively weaker medium-strong acid sites are more conducive to desulfurization. The synthesis of Cu25/MCM-41 and Ce25/MCM-41 resulted in the formation of new, robust acidic sites in comparison to MCM-41. The Cu25/MCM-41 sample exhibited a greater number of these acidic sites than Ce25/MCM-41. When the bimetallic was simultaneously loaded onto the surface of MCM-41, the Cu25/MCM-41 sample displayed an enhanced intensity of weakly acidic sites. The Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 data were consistent with those of Cu25/MCM-41, indicating that the weakly acidic sites produced by CuO were the dominant species. The presence of two major characteristic peaks in the medium-strong acidic sites of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 is attributed to the superposition of the medium-strong acidic sites of Cu25/MCM-41 and Ce25/MCM-41. Furthermore, the intensity of the meso‑strong acidic sites produced at 377 °C is enhanced, potentially influenced by the addition of CeOx species. The intensity and number of strong acidic sites of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 exhibit a slight decline compared to Cu25/MCM-41, attributed to the incorporation of Ce, which partially covers the Cu component. Prior research has demonstrated that weakly and moderately strong acidic sites can facilitate the physical and chemical adsorption of acidic gases, respectively [11]. However, strongly acidic sites can accelerate catalyst deactivation by further oxidizing reaction products, such as H2S, to generate sulfur-containing species [26]. Therefore, the incorporation of Ce not only enhances the number and strength of strongly acidic sites in Cu25/MCM-41 but also reduces the number and intensity. This resulted in a notable enhancement of the desulfurization performance of Cu25/MCM-41. The basic sites mainly affect the catalytic hydrolysis process of COS on the catalyst surface. CO2-TPD was used to detect the alkaline species on the sample surface and the number of corresponding sites. As shown in Fig. 8 , the basic strength of the catalysts can be classified into weakly basic (50–300 °C), moderately basic (300–575 °C), and strongly basic (575–800 °C) based on the position of CO2 desorption peaks, where the weakly basic sites corresponded to the -OH groups, the moderately basic sites corresponded to the M-O pairs (M = Cu, Si, and Ce), and the strongly basic sites corresponded to the O2- ions [40]. The MCM- 41 showed a significant increase in the weakly basic sites on the surface after loading Cu and Ce, respectively. Meanwhile, the number of weakly basic sites of Cu25/MCM-41 was more than that of Ce25/MCM-41 with the same basic strength. This indicates that CuO and CeOx produce similar weakly basic sites on the surface of MCM-41. The number of moderately basic sites of Ce25/MCM-41 increased significantly after the addition of Ce, which indicated that Ce could effectively enhance the moderately basic sites of MCM-41. The intensities of the strongly basic sites on the surfaces of Cu25/MCM-41 and Ce25/MCM-41 decreased, and the intensity of the strongly basic sites on the surface of Cu25/MCM-41 was lower. Combined with the results of the desulfurization experiments, the stronger strongly basic sites are not conducive to the catalytic removal of organic sulfur. When the bimetallic was loaded on the surface of MCM-41 at the same time, the intensity of the weakly basic sites of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 was slightly increased due to the synergistic effect of Cu and Ce to increase the variety of weakly basic sites on the surface. The intensity and number of moderately basic sites of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 were found to be significantly higher than those of Cu25/MCM-41. This change can be attributed to the presence of moderately basic sites produced by Ce. The intensity and number of strongly basic sites of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 exhibited a decrease compared to Cu25/MCM-41. Additionally, there was a shift from strongly basic sites to stronger moderately basic sites. This is attributed to the synergistic effect of Cu and Ce, whereby Cu25/MCM-41 covers part of the Cu fraction after loading a small amount of Ce. Consequently, the number of both weakly and strongly basic sites of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 decreased, while the number of moderately basic sites increased. The alkaline strength of the weakly basic sites is enhanced, while the alkalinity of the moderately strong basic sites is diminished, due to the presence of a considerable number of Ce3+ in the Ce oxide. The presence of these Ce3+ causes a shift in the alkalinity of both the weakly and strongly basic sites toward a moderately alkaline state [41]. While the basic sites are the primary active sites for catalytic hydrolysis of COS, excessive alkalinity can lead to the oxidation of the hydrolysis product H2S of COS, which is detrimental to the catalytic hydrolysis of COS [42]. The Cu25/MCM-41 composite provides a substantial number of basic sites for the catalytic hydrolysis of COS, thereby markedly enhancing the desulfurization performance of MCM-41. While a certain quantity of basic sites are also generated on the surface of Ce25/MCM-41, its activation capacity for COS is relatively weak, resulting in a less pronounced improvement in desulfurization performance. The number and strength of strong basic sites on the surface of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 are reduced in comparison to Cu25/MCM-41. Additionally, the formation of new medium-strong basic sites is diminished in comparison to that of Cu25/MCM-41, and new medium-strong alkaline sites are formed. This alteration is advantageous in mitigating the oxidation of H2S, which is beneficial in enhancing the desulfurization performance. It can thus be concluded that the weakly and strongly basic sites generated by CuO can provide a large number of active sites for the reaction in the catalytic hydrolysis of COS. Concurrently, CeOx effectively diminishes the number and intensity of strongly basic sites while facilitating the formation of more moderately basic sites. The combined effect of Cu and Ce is a significant contributor to the enhanced adsorption and the slowing down of the oxidation of H2S by COS. H2-TPR is capable of reducing metal cations with high valence states to low valence states, thereby determining the valence existence form of metal cations within the sample. As illustrated in Fig. 9 , the reduction peaks of Cu25/MCM-41 at 207 °C and 275 °C are attributed to the reduction of small and large particles of CuO to Cu monomers, respectively. The formation of a reduction peak between 350 and 600 °C in Ce25/MCM-41 is ascribed to the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ [43]. The H2 consumption is diminished in comparison to Cu25/MCM-41, and the reduction peak is shifted to higher temperatures, indicating that the added Ce partially covers part of the CuO and forms a Cu-Ce metallic bond. This finding is in accordance with the preceding characterization results. Furthermore, due to the coverage of Ce on the Cu surface, the deactivation of Cu can be slowed down, thereby improving the desulfurization performance of the catalyst. 3.4 Product analysis and deactivation process To elucidate the changes in elements and functional groups at the surface of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 during the desulfurization process and to determine the properties of the product, EDS, XPS, and FTIR characterization were carried out. The EDS spectrogram (Fig. 3) and elemental content analysis (Table 2) demonstrated that the Cu and Ce in the Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalyst (Fig. 3f) were uniformly dispersed throughout the sample. A substantial number of sulfur-containing species were identified on the surface of the deactivated Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalyst (Fig. 3g). These species originated from sulfides produced by the combination of H2S and the surface-active components or sulfur-containing species produced by the further oxidation of H2S. The accumulation of these sulfur-containing species on the surface of the catalyst resulted in catalyst deactivation [44]. The Cu fraction in the deactivated Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 is covered by sulfur-containing species, resulting in a decrease in the Cu content on the surface of the deactivated catalyst. The oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of the catalyst undergo a reaction that reduces the amount of O atoms, while the Si and Ce atoms remain unaffected, leading to an increase in their content. This also indicates that Ce exhibits high resistance to sulfur poisoning. As illustrated in Fig. 4 and Table 3 , the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter of the utilized Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalysts exhibited a slight increase in comparison to that of the Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalysts. This was attributed to the fact that the small pores of the used Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalysts were blocked by sulfur-containing species, which were then dispersed to produce a new pore structure on the surface of the catalysts. This resulted in a slight change in the pore parameters of the catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 6, the generation of Cu+ was observed in the deactivated Cu25Ce5/MCM-41, while Ce3+ was no longer present on the surface. This suggests that Cu2+ and Ce3+ were directly involved in the oxidation of H2S. Therefore, the consumption of Cu2+ and Ce3+ accelerated the deactivation of the catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 10 , the presence of characteristic peaks for S2-, S, SO3 2-, and SO4 2- on the surface of the deactivated Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalyst indicates that the by-product H2S undergoes oxidation to S, SO3 2-, and SO4 2- by oxygen-containing groups on the catalyst surface. The mass percentages of S2-, S, SO3 2-, and SO4 2- species were characterized by XPS as 26.29 %, 20.64 %, 24.01 %, and 29.06 %, respectively. This is slightly lower than the theoretical desulfurization, which can be attributed to the presence of residual H2S on the catalyst surface in the form of adsorption. As illustrated in Fig. 11 , the FTIR results reveal that the absorption peaks at 3420 cm-1 and 1638 cm-1 are attributed to OH stretching and bending of water molecules, respectively. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching absorption peaks of Si-O-Si are found at 1229 cm-1 and 799 cm-1, respectively. This is due to the fact that the main composition of MCM-41 is SiO2. The peaks at 2924 cm-1 and 2854 cm-1 are generated by the symmetric and asymmetric stretching of CH, respectively. The absorption peaks at 968 cm-1 correspond to the vibration of the silanol group Si-OH. The peak at 1060 cm-1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of S=O. The peaks at 1920 cm-1 and 1870 cm-1 are indicative of the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of C=O, respectively. The depletion of OH and Si-OH on the surface of deactivated Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 is involved in the hydrolysis reaction of COS. The depletion of C=O and the production of S=O indicate that the oxidation of H2S occurs on the surface of the catalyst. The production of CH indicates that H2O molecules are dissociated on the surface of the catalyst. It can thus be concluded that the hydrolysis of COS and oxidation of H2S on the catalyst surface are determined by the presence of OH, Si-OH, and C=O. The migration process of the S element in COS can be inferred from the generated products. Firstly, COS adsorbed on the catalyst surface undergoes hydrolysis, resulting in the transformation of the S element into H2S. Subsequently, H2S adsorbed on the catalyst surface undergoes partial oxidation to sulfide, and partial oxidation to S, SO3 2-, and SO4 2- under the action of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface. These sulfur-containing species are deposited on the surface of the catalyst, leading to the poisoning and deactivation of the catalyst. The kinetic models are as follows (Eq. (2)). The hydrolysis reaction of COS is close to a first-order kinetic reaction. (2) − r ( COS ) = 612.68 × e ( − 28.64 R T ) × C ( COS ) 0.897 × C ( H 2 O ) 0.215 A reaction mechanism for the catalytic hydrolysis of COS was proposed on the basis of the performance of the Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 catalyst and the characterization analysis of the catalyst before and after deactivation. As shown in Fig. 12 , the mechanism is as follows: The sequence of events begins with H2O dissociating into H+ and OH- under the influence of surface-active oxygen. Subsequently, COS is adsorbed on OH- due to the action of an ion dipole. The strength of the C=S bond, being lower than that of the C=O bond, leads to the breakage of the C=S bond, resulting in the formation of a C-S bond. Furthermore, S in O=C-S readily combines with the hydroxyl group on the catalyst surface, thereby forming an S-H bond and yielding an intermediate product, HSCO2 -. Finally, H+ reacts with HSCO2 - to generate CO2 and H2S. 4 Conclusions In this study, Cu-Ce bimetallic-modified MCM-41 hydrolysis catalysts were prepared and evaluated for their synergistic desulfurization with various metals. The desulfurization efficiency of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 can reach a 100 % COS removal rate and maintain for 3.5 h. It was demonstrated that CuO was the primary active component in the catalysis of hydrolysis. In the context of catalytic hydrolysis of COS, the weak and strong alkaline sites generated by CuO can provide a substantial number of active sites for the reaction. Concurrently, CeOx effectively diminishes the number and potency of strongly basic sites, while augmenting the availability of moderately basic sites. The combined effect of Cu and Ce was instrumental in enhancing the adsorption of COS and mitigating the oxidation of H2S. The deactivated catalyst surface produced S2-, S, SO3 2-, and SO4 2- species, indicating that the product H2S would be oxidized to S, SO3 2-, and SO4 2- by oxygen-containing groups on the catalyst surface. Additionally, a depletion of Cu2+ and Ce3+ occurred, leading to catalyst deactivation. CRediT authorship contribution statement Kaixuan Yan: Investigation, Writing – original draft, Visualization. coredata.dc:description: The presence of sulfur-containing impurities in natural gas not only diminishes its utilization value, but also results in the emission of sulfur-containing pollutants. In this study, a Cu-Ce bimetallic-loaded MCM-41 catalyst was prepared by ammonia evaporation method for the catalytic hydrolysis of carbonyl sulfide (COS). The desulfurization efficiency of Cu25Ce5/MCM-41 can reach a 100 % COS removal rate and maintain for 3.5 h. CuO furnishes the predominant weakly acidic and weakly basic sites for the desulfurization process, which are conducive to the adsorption of COS. Meanwhile, CeOx provides a greater abundance of moderately basic sites for the desulfurization process, which help to improve the removal efficiency of COS. The incorporation of Ce into the catalyst enhances the resistance to sulfur poisoning of Cu and prolongs the lifespan of the catalyst. The incorporation of Ce is capable of transforming the strongly basic sites on the surface of Cu25/MCM-41 into moderately basic sites, avoiding excessive oxidation of H2S. Additionally, the introduction of Ce offers a degree of protection for CuO, which improves the ability of the catalyst to resist sulfur poisoning. The combined effect of Cu and Ce was found to be instrumental in enhancing the adsorption of COS and in slowing down the oxidation of H2S. The reduction of Cu2+ and Ce3+ indicated their direct participation in the oxidation of H2S. Firstly, COS adsorbed on the catalyst surface is converted into H2S and CO2 through a catalytic hydrolysis reaction. Subsequently, H2S adsorbed on the catalyst surface undergoes partial oxidation to sulfide, and partial further oxidation by oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface to S, SO3 2-, and SO4 2-, which results in the toxic deactivation of the catalyst.
